title: apps.owncloud.com: Session Cookie in URL can be captured by hackers

profile.name: ownCloud
profile.about: ownCloud GmbH is the company behind the ownCloud Project - the most downloaded open source project for data and file sync, share and view.

vulnerability_information:
Session Cookie in URL
URL: https://apps.owncloud.com/stories/feed+rss
  
Issue detail
The URL in the request appears to contain a PHP Session token within the query string:

https://apps.owncloud.com/stories/feed+rss?id=42590&PHPSESSID=ee0624300266683a4625aabea344212a
  

Issue background
Sensitive information within URLs may be logged in various locations, including the user's browser, the web server, and any forward or reverse proxy servers between the two endpoints. URLs may also be displayed on-screen, bookmarked or emailed around by users. **They may be disclosed to third parties via the Referer header when any off-site links are followed**. Placing session tokens into the URL increases the risk that they will be captured by an attacker.  

Issue remediation
Applications should use an alternative mechanism for transmitting session tokens, such as HTTP cookies or hidden fields in forms that are submitted using the POST method.  


Note: In your webpage, all `<a href=` contain PHPSESSID URL Parameter, which further increases this risk.
vulnerability_information_html:
Session Cookie in URL
URL: https://apps.owncloud.com/stories/feed+rss

Issue detail
The URL in the request appears to contain a PHP Session token within the query string:

https://apps.owncloud.com/stories/feed+rss?id=42590&PHPSESSID=ee0624300266683a4625aabea344212a

Issue background
Sensitive information within URLs may be logged in various locations, including the user's browser, the web server, and any forward or reverse proxy servers between the two endpoints. URLs may also be displayed on-screen, bookmarked or emailed around by users. They may be disclosed to third parties via the Referer header when any off-site links are followed. Placing session tokens into the URL increases the risk that they will be captured by an attacker.

Issue remediation
Applications should use an alternative mechanism for transmitting session tokens, such as HTTP cookies or hidden fields in forms that are submitted using the POST method.

Note: In your webpage, all <a href= contain PHPSESSID URL Parameter, which further increases this risk.

activities.message:
Thanks. I can confirm this configuration problem and will escalate this to the platform owner.

However, please note that for the time being we do not award monetary rewards for bugs reported for our own website. – We will however acknowledge this and mark this as valid bug.

From our FAQ:
> **Q: Why do you exclude the ownCloud websites?**
A: For the time being we want to focus our efforts on ownCloud Server instead of vulnerabilities within our website. However, if you find a security bug in our website we welcome any report, though we cannot offer a monetary incentive.

activities.message:
Hi,
i think you should take it seriously as its a valid issue.
one can't ignore this mistake.. there are many tools available in market to sniff and then decrypt traffic ..
So,patch it ASAP :)
regads,,

activities.message: The owner of the platform believes this issue has been addressed and a check on our side has proved that the `PHPSESSID` has disappeared from the links generated by the platform. We consider this issue thus fixed.
activities.markdown_message: The owner of the platform believes this issue has been addressed and a check on our side has proved that the PHPSESSID has disappeared from the links generated by the platform. We consider this issue thus fixed.

activities.message:
Thanks a lot for your report. Please note that for the time being we do not award monetary rewards for bugs reported for our own website and infrastructure.

From our FAQ:
> **Q: Why do you exclude the ownCloud websites and infrastructure?**
> A: For the time being we want to focus our efforts on ownCloud Server instead of vulnerabilities within our website and infrastructure. However, if you find a security bug in our website or infrastructure we welcome any report, though we cannot offer a monetary incentive.

If you want to ensure that your submission are in-scope you might want to try the code available from https://owncloud.org/install/
